pros: This was a great place to work. The staff and management were friendly and supportive and we worked well as a team. The company offers a very generous benefit package including medical and dental insurance, retirement plan and great sick leave and vacation leave policy. If you follow the guidelines and make an effort to get along and get your work done, this is an ideal job. You don't have someone watching over you constantly - you are free to get the job done on your own as long as the job gets done. The management team is supportive and easy to approach with questions and concerns.
cons: I appreciated the stability of a mature and carefully run organization. However, if someone is not serious or underperforms, then IERF would not be for that person.

review_title: Good work opportunity to learn stuff
pros: Learning process is good and beneficial
cons: Bad management with limited bonus/ perks

pros:
- Comprehensive training process.

- Consistent work hours. Little need for overtime if you're efficient in managing your workload.

- Strong benefits package.

- Zero micromanagement: management is entirely hands-off. This may appeal to some more than others.

- *usually* Approachable and friendly staff.
cons:
- Limited growth trajectory.

- Occasional poor communication between staff and management. Senior level employees can be inconsistent in their application / understanding of policies.

- Lack of a cohesive office culture / too impersonal. This may bother some more than others, but the office is VERY quiet and few staff members interact with each other on a regular basis. I believe this is a consequence of both the nature of the work (95% of the time spent on a computer, sending e-mails, inputting data etc.) and  the quantity of work. While it never got to be too much for me, you will remain busy and will feel that you have little time for conversation with your colleagues, especially if you wish to avoid overtime.

pros:
-Policies are clearly outlined and applied evenly across all staff
-Their database system is top notch and incredibly well-organized
-Long-term employees are great resources of knowledge and always willing to help
-They are willing to invest in growth of their employees
-Get in at 8, off at 4:30.
cons:
-Daily work can be monotonous and confusing (although it is not the fault of IERF)
-Email system is not searchable for time periods prior to your employment

review_title: Great Office and People for a Good Cause
pros:
For the record, as a former employee, let me clarify that I unfortunately had to leave due to a personal issue on the other side of the country, so in no way did I leave because of a "toxic environment." I actually saw the other review for this company and figured I'd leave an honest review from a former employee who didn't leave disgruntled.

This is a very quiet, small office environment of about 30-40 employees, all incredibly nice and helpful. When I actually walked in for the first time and heard how many employees there were, I was shocked because it was so quiet. I never had an issue with management and they always treated me with respect and reviewed my work without bias. The only negative thing they ever said to me in a review of my work was when they politely asked me to tidy my desk (which was warranted).

Although the training is extensive, it's understandably necessary once you start your work (I worked as an evaluator). You get to learn the education systems of multiple foreign countries as well as other protocols (verifying official documents, learning degree equivalencies, etc.) One thing that greatly appealed to me about the office is how much is done independently. Once you have your training, you're given files and sit quietly at your desk in your own space- something that would definitely appeal to someone who prefers to work alone rather than in a group. At the same time, all of the evaluators (as well as support team) are very personable and willing to help as you'll quickly learn that no file/application is ever the same, so it may occasionally take more than two evaluators to come to a conclusion regarding an applicant's studies. However, you're never put down for asking questions (I asked many) and if anything encouraged to do so to ensure no details go by unseen. 

I feel very lucky that I got the chance to work for IERF as now I'll be able to hold onto my training and will have this information for the rest of my career. Although education credentials is not something I ever believed I would get into (or even really knew existed), it is quite valuable information that I can now apply to multiple positions at colleges and universities.
cons: For the record, every office has its pros and cons. One thing I would caution future employees here is that, as an evaluator for foreign education credentials, policies and stipulations for every country change on a daily basis. You may be just getting used to a policy for a specific institution or country, and before you know it, some Ministry of Education will change their requirements which in turn changes the companies. Of course these things happen at many companies, but it is seen more frequently in an environment dealing with practically every single country.

pros: There really isn’t any substantial pros to be honest.
cons: I wouldn’t recommend working with this company. They are extremely understaffed which leads to poor communication and lack of proper training. Middle management is very incompetent, disorganized, extremely hostile, and lack true leadership skills, and would rather blame the staff they are in charge of overseeing rather than take accountability for their own errors in training and protocol. There is absolutely no career growth in this company and management makes it very clear your replaceable. Lastly, the overall work environment is quiet and very unwelcoming, co-workers rarely engage unless absolutely necessary or in short meetings.

pros: Stable employment, immediate feedback, coworkers are friendly and supportive, management is available, sufficient training is provided, benefits and vacation packages are generous, strong relationship amongst employees
cons: for evaluators, there is limited upward mobility. standards and procedures can change rapidly, and reasoning may be opaque. you are expected to follow standards that are unavailable due to their predating your hire.

job_title: Credentials Evaluator in Culver City, CA
pros: You know what to expect everyday.
cons: Everything Else. Short break, attitude, ego, pay, treatment.

pros: You are left to do your job on your own most of the time - a pro for introverts.
cons: Antagonistic management, aggressive communication style. Management is not there to guide and support, but to find faults and blame - that's their main role: Fault finding. Very demoralizing for new staff eager to learn and do well. Also, no advancement opportunities. Low-pay, boring, dead end job!

review_title: a work place you should avoid
pros: coworkers are super nice and easy to get along with
cons:
bad pay and management, 
boring work

pros: great place to work all the time
cons: no real cons good solid place

review_title: Very challenging and toxic place (should be zero stars!)
job_title: Adjunct Professor in Randolph Center, VT
pros: Some students are prepared and make the work seem important. Flexible scheduling
cons: A decade of deferred maintenance means unsafe and ADA non-compliant buildings. No support from administration. Laughably antiquated technology. Many under prepared students being pushed through create extra work. Insulting low compensation packages.

pros: Short hours and no summers
cons: No resourses, no leadership, old and broken technology, overloaded schedules

pros: Adjunct faculty had solid orientation and lots of support
cons: Minimal budget for adjunct faculty

review_title: Resident Assistant was not the job I thought it was
job_title: Resident Assistant in Randolph Center, VT
pros: Fun atmosphere, and a good way to make friends. I did like the job in the beginning, it offered a lot of opportunities to plan fun hall events and dorm-wide activities. My residents were very respectful of dorm regulations, and duty nights were very quiet.
cons: An unorganized, sometimes frustrating job because my responsibilities were not clear. Planning on other RA's parts and RD's parts was pretty much nonexistent. Planning events or meetings was like pulling teeth.

review_title: A great starting point for junior software folks.
pros: You get to work in a real world environment on a small team of students. Everyone is learning and helps each-other along the way. It's basically an intensive class that you get paid to do.
cons: You do get paid, but it is low for a software job. It's definitely something that you'll only do for a summer or two.

pros: VTC is well focused on students and learning and allows instructors the opportuinty to control what and how they teach.
cons: The pay is not as high as the Universities in the area, in addition the teaching load is substantially higher than competing institutions

pros: People are great.  VTC serves a great need for the community. The students are great too and seem appreciative and work hard... for the most part.
cons: Budget is tight, so we all have to be creative. It's nice to have the latest, greatest equipment, etc, but that's not always possible.

job_title: Assistant Chief Technical Officer in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Nice People!  Very nice Williston Campus.
cons: State of Vermont is high in living cost and pay is sub-par.  For Vermont the wages at the college are good but you can do much better in other parts of the country.

job_title: IT Senior Desktop Support in Essex Junction, VT
pros: Great People. Good 401k contribution.
cons: Too many chiefs, too many committees, not enough action.

job_title: Helpdesk Technician in Randolph Center, VT
pros: Great atmosphere, knowledgeable staff, great working environment
cons: Small community in a rural area

job_title: Network and Computer Systems Administrator in Randolph, VT
pros: great retirement and medical coverage
cons: limited pay scale raises or promotions in grade

pros: Fellow faculty are nice. Misery loves company
cons: Dirty classrooms, zero tech support, employee performance metrics are student popularity contests, ridiculously low compensation.
